I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  In  March  2004,  during  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  Country  Programming 
Mission, the Government of Bhutan requested technical assistance (TA) to prepare a project for 
improving urban infrastructure and services. The TA Fact-Finding Mission was fielded from 31 
August to 8 September 2004 and held discussions with the Government and other aid agencies, 
including  the  United  Nations  Development  Programme,  Danish  International  Development 
Agency  (DANIDA),  and  Japan  International  Cooperation  Agency.  The  Mission  met  with 
responsible officials of the concerned government agencies, including the Department of Aid 
and Debt Management in the Ministry of Finance, Ministry of Works and Human Settlement 
(MoWHS), Thimphu City Corporation, Phuentsholing  City  Corporation,  and  Dagana  District 
Administration. This TA was developed on the basis of an understanding reached during the 
Mission. The preliminary loan project framework is attached as Appendix 1.1 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Bhutan is a landlocked country in the Eastern Himalayas, covering approximately 36,364 
square kilometers of mostly mountainous terrain. Prior to the early 1960s, Bhutan was isolated 
from the rest of the world and its overwhelming rural population was entirely dependent on 
subsistence agriculture. Since embarking on a modernization process in 1961, Bhutan has 
made great progress in improving the standard of living of its people. The Royal Government of 
Bhutan's  development  strategy  has  focused  on  striking  a  balance  between  growth  in 
productivity and incomes, and a desire to preserve its cultural and environmental heritage. 
Adopting  ”gross  national  happiness”2  as  a  philosophy  and  objective  of  the  country's 
development, the Government identified four main avenues toward achieving this objective: 
economic  growth  and  development,  preservation  and  promotion  of  cultural  heritage, 
preservation and sustainable use of the environment, and good governance. 
 
3.  Priorities  for  development,  as  defined  by  the  Government  are  human  resources 
development and the improvement of physical infrastructure (such as roads suitable for motor 
vehicles), telecommunications, energy, and transportation. These areas have been considered 
as  essential  elements  for  increasing  the  national  productivity:  Agriculture;  hydropower 
generation; tourism; and manufacturing, mining, and construction activities contribute to the 
growth of the national economy. The average growth rate of gross domestic product from 1993 
to 2001 was 6.5%, but it grew by 7.7% in fiscal year 2002.  
 
4.  Bhutan is already experiencing signs of urban growth pressures. Urban settlement is a 
new phenomenon with a quickening pace in the last 15 to 20 years. The beginning of urban 
settlement  in  Bhutan  was  the  establishment  of  Dzongkhag  (provincial)  centers, currently 
numbering  20.  These  centers  began  as  administrative  and  religious  entities  rather  than 
commercial and industrial ones. The population in 2002 for the total country was 716,424,3 and 
the urban population is estimated at 21% of the total population. The population growth rate is 
computed at 2.5% based on the National Health Statistics 2000. Other sources4 set the national 
growth rate at 3.1% per annum. At this rate, the country's population would double over 25 
years. With arable land at only 10% of the total land area, the increased population cannot be 
accommodated in the agriculture sector. 
 
5.  ADB’s  strategy  for  development  assistance  to  Bhutan,  articulated  in  the  Country 
Strategy and Program Update (2005-2006), focuses mainly on reducing poverty through rural

electrification, road network expansion and infrastructure improvements in regional centers, and 
basic skills development. Physical isolation is identified in the Government’s ninth 5-year plan5 
as the main cause of poverty. The two major cities, Thimphu and Phuentsholing, are facing the 
full force of urban migration and urban sprawls linked to limited job opportunities in the rural 
areas. The task of absorbing 70,000 people expected to enter the labor market during the 
period covered by the Ninth 5-year plan (2002–2007) is quite challenging, given the low 
employment elasticity of the power sector, which is the largest industry. The unemployment rate 
in the country is still 2–3%, but in urban areas, the rate is 4.1%; among those aged 15–19 
years, the urban unemployment figure is as high as 10.9%.6  An  initial  poverty  and  social 
assessment is included as Appendix 2.  
 
6.  The Government is responding to the increase in urbanization with a number of policy 
documents including Ninth 5-year plan and Vision 2020.7 Various programs are already in place 
to draw into or retain people within secondary centers instead of the major centers. In Vision 
2020, the Government emphasized the great importance of securing equality in the living 
standard of various parts of the country, "to ensure that the benefits of development are shared 
equitably between different income groups and regions and in ways that promotes social 
harmony, stability and unity and contribute to the development of a just and compassionate 
society." This requires special measures in support of disadvantaged and vulnerable groups as 
well  as  efforts  to  ensure  that  those  who  have  been  largely  bypassed  by  the  benefits  of 
development are drawn more fully into the mainstream of the development process. With this 
requirement in mind, the Government requested continued ADB assistance in improving the 
urban infrastructure and services needs in Thimphu and Phuentsholing, particularly in their 
respective newly expanded areas.8 It also asked for help in developing some regional centers 
unassisted by any other source of aid in the past.9  
 
7.   Population by city and town are not disaggregated, and numbers vary from source to 
source.  For  this  TA,  Thimphu's  population  is  estimated  at  53,000  and  Phuentsholing's  at 
18,00010 with annual growth rates of 7% and less than 3%, respectively. Thimphu is growing at 
more than double the national growth rate, predominantly as a result of rural-urban migration. Its 
population is projected to reach 150,000 by 2027. Thimphu  is an administrative center with 
almost half of the city's population estimated to rely in one way or another on a government 
wage. Thimphu's relatively isolated location limits industrial development. Economic activity is 
based on the retailing of goods and services to the population.  
 
8.  In  2001,  10  neighboring  areas  of  old  Thimphu  city  were  incorporated  into  greater 
Thimphu City. Previously, the Government had identified these areas as urban villages in the 
Structural Plan11 and Ninth 5-year plan. Among the 10 extended areas, four have completed 
their own structural plan: Lungtenphu, Babesa, Taba, and Dechencholing. Including the 10 new 
areas, urban services coverage within greater Thimphu is still very low. In particular, only 30%

Paved roads connect 30% of the whole Thimphu population.  
 
9.  After Thimphu, opportunity seekers end up in Phuentsholing searching for a livelihood as 
the city is home to the country's major industries and is the major entry point into India, Bhutan's 
largest trading partner. By virtue of its location on the Indo-Bhutan border, by the late 1970s and 
early 1980s, Phuentsholing has developed rapidly from a small settlement to being referred to 
as the "commercial capital". The city is simultaneously a commercial, industrial, institutional, and 
administrative center. Its problems stem from the fact that the growth of the town has not been 
met by improvement in its infrastructure. Phuentsholing is, however, an exception, where, in 
spite of many projections to the contrary, the population growth is slow, barely matching that of 
the nation as a whole. The main constraint to such growth is the lack of land and appropriate 
housing.  
 
10.   There are areas still yet to be served by basic infrastructure facilities in Phuentsholing. 
Newly expanding areas have no water supply and no sewerage, although they have been 
attracting a migrant population in the past decade due to a shortage of land and housing in the 
center of the city. Adding to this plight, the population and traffic pressures in the city core are 
getting worse. There are no paved roads from the city center to those emerging expanded 
subdistricts. Limited parking spaces, heavy vehicles from India, and traffic jams on a handful of 
large streets in the central part of town are causing further environmental decay. Increasing 
commercialization also exacerbates traffic problems, noise, and air pollution.  
 
11.   The government exercise in 1992 that identified and categorized various levels of urban 
environment took into consideration such features as population, hospitals, schools, industrial 
base, water, shops, restaurants, and public transport connections and assigned points based on 
a measure of these features.12 Thimphu and Phuentsholing were the only urban areas in the 
country to be labeled Category A. Category B and C towns and villages have been identified as 
Urban Centers (28 in total), and category Ds are now known as Satellite Towns (26). Dagana, 
the administrative capital of Daga Dzongkhag is approximately 240 kilometers away from 
Thimphu, taking 8 hours on winding roads and steep hills. From the National Highway,13 any 
vehicle  will  have  to  endure  bumpy  and  steep  dirt  roads  for  approximately  2  hours. 
Encompassing villages on the mountain hills in the area, Dagana is a population center of 
7,000–8,000 people. The whole dzongkhag has population of 21,000. Among which, only 2,000 
people in central Dagana have piped water supply. However the source is often contaminated 
by flash flood or animal discharge. Not only does the rest of the urban population of 6,000 need 
water supply, but also the existing network covering 2,000 people requires major overhaul. The 
governor listed the priorities for investment as first, water supply and second, urban roads within 
the city. The dzongkhag wants to align and pave the dirt road in the town; link newly built 
primary schools; create commercial subzones; and provide basic urban facilities, such as a 
vegetable market, for its population.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
12.  The main objective of the TA is to prepare an investment project to improve the urban 
infrastructure and services in Thimphu, Phuentsholing, and one or two high-priority urban 
centers  that  have  not  yet  received  external  assistance.  This  objective  supports  the

A towns are those that scored 36 points or above.

Government's policy of balanced regional development and decentralization. Output of the TA 
will be an investment package for basic urban services (e.g., water supply and sanitation, solid 
waste management, roads, riverbank protection, retaining walls and storm drainage, public 
parking and other facilities such as a vegetable market). The TA will also help the Government 
in improving the management of regional centers, including training dzongkhag-level officials, 
strengthening financial management of dzongkhag financing related to urban infrastructure and 
operation and maintenance (including policies and remedial actions to stop unwanted urban 
sprawl) in transparent manner. The final output of the TA will provide the basis for possible ADB 
investment in the urban infrastructure and services provision in urban localities.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
13.   The TA will have two main components: (i) assessment of the civil works requirements 
and costs for improving urban facilities for Thimphu’s extended areas, Phuentsholing City, and 
selected  regional  center(s);  and  (ii)  analysis  of  the  policy,  financial,  and  administrative 
processes  required  to  enhance  the  capacity  of  dzongkhag  administrators to operate and 
manage urban facilities.  
 
14.   The  TA  will  (i)  through  local  hearings  and  other  means  consult  with  expected 
beneficiaries,  especially  low-income  households  in  poorly  served  areas,  other  sources  of 
external assistance, two city corporations, government agencies, and community and business 
leaders; (ii) assess the current and projected land and infrastructure requirements for enhanced 
urban services; (iii) conduct demand assessments, projections, and willingness-to-pay for the 
improved infrastructure and services; (iv) develop the design, master plan, and layout for the 
improvements;  (v)  conduct  an  initial  environmental  examination  and  social  analysis  in 
accordance with ADB's guidelines and recommended appropriate mitigation measures; (vi) draft 
a resettlement plan; and (vii) carry out economic and financial analysis for the ensuing project. 
 
15.   The  assessment  of  the  policy  setting  as  well  as  the  financial  and  administrative 
environment will (i) review the policies and guidelines related to urban infrastructure provision in 
Bhutan to identify critical constraints; (ii) review similar studies conducted by the World Bank 
and  DANIDA14  and  review  the  implementation  actions  adopted  in  respective  target  urban 
centers;  (iii)  help  establish  an  appropriate  legal  framework  and  recommend  rules  and 
regulations to support dhongkhags; (iv) recommend administrative and technical procedures for 
the  operation  and  maintenance  of  the  facilities;  and  (v)  establish  clear  and  transparent 
procedures for private sector participation in the operation of urban facilities.  
 
16.  All the proposed activities will be carried out in collaboration with pertinent government 
agencies and the private sector. An effort will also be made to create strong linkages with the 
urban development programs of the World Bank and DANIDA.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
17.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $727,000 equivalent of which $515,000 will be 
foreign exchange costs, and $212,000 equivalent will be local currency costs. ADB will finance 
$600,000 equivalent, which includes the entire foreign exchange cost and $85,000 equivalent in 
local currency costs. The remaining $127,000 will be contributed by the Government and will 
include office accommodation, utilities, remuneration of counterpart staff, local transportation, 
surveys, and workshops. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Special Fund,

funded by the Government of Japan. The Government has been informed that approval of the 
TA does not commit ADB to finance  any ensuing project. The detailed cost estimates and

D.  Implementation Arrangements 
18.  MoWHS will be the Executing Agency for the TA. The TA will be implemented through 
the Department of Urban Development and Engineering Services (DUDES) within MoWHS. 
MoWHS will set up a TA implementing unit; appoint a manager for the unit; and provide office 
space, furniture, equipment, and counterpart staff for the TA consultants as necessary. DUDES 
will provide counterpart technical staff to the TA consultants as required. MoWHS will ensure 
that the National Planning department in the Ministry of Finance, Thimphu City Corporation, 
Phuentsholing  City  Corporation,  Department  of  Public  Health,  and  National  Environment 
Commission are closely involved in the TA, and that their concerns are fully considered. The 
Government will continue to sustain the Technical Assistance Steering Committee already 
established under another ADB TA15 to periodically review the progress of the TA and resolve 
any issues that may arise. The steering committee will meet at least once every 2 months. It will 
be chaired by the director general of the Department of Aid and Debt Management and will 
include representatives from DUDES, MoWHS, National Planning department in the Ministry of 
Finance, National Environment Commission, and the two city corporations. All representatives 
in the steering committee will be at least director-level officials.  
 
19.  The TA will be implemented over a period of 7 months from April to October 2005. The 
consulting team will comprise 20 person-months of international consulting services and 21 
person-months of domestic consulting services. All consultants will be selected and engaged by 
ADB in accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants by the Asian Development 
Bank and Its Borrowers and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for the engagement of 
domestic consultants. Terms of reference for the consulting services are provided in Appendix 
4. The simplified technical proposal format and the quality-and-cost-based selection method will 
be used. Office equipment will be procured by the respective consultant in accordance with 
ADB's Guidelines for Procurement.  
 
20.  The  consultants  will  submit  short  monthly  progress  reports  summarizing  activities, 
issues, and constraints throughout the duration of the TA. In addition, four major reports will be 
submitted. An inception report will be submitted no later than 3 weeks after fielding of the 
consultants. A midterm report will be submitted no later than 2 months after TA inception, and a 
draft final report will be submitted 5 months after inception. The Government and ADB will 
provide comments on the draft final report. The final report will be submitted within 3 weeks after 
receiving comments from the review.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
21.   The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $600,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Bhutan for preparing the Urban Infrastructure Development Project, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.

A.  Linkages to the Country Poverty Analysis

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in Bhutan: 
The land area is approximately 36,000 square kilometers with only approximately 10% of the landmass being 
cultivated or inhabited. Approximately one quarter of the people living in Bhutan are poor, without financial resources 
beyond what they need to meet basic needs. Overall, poverty is concentrated in rural areas where households 
continue to rely on subsistence agriculture without adequate access to enough land, key transport, and community 
infrastructures. The incidence of poverty is higher among the households with subsistence agriculture and agricultural 
laborers. The urban population has lower level of poverty, however in the smaller towns, the incidence of poverty is 
slightly higher.  
 
In the four decades, since the Government of Bhutan initiated a period of modernization, many indicators of the 
welfare and quality of life of Bhutanese have shown significant improvement especially in the health, education, 
physical facilities, and transport. However, rapid growth of population will place increasing pressures on the land and 
other natural resources that support rural livelihoods. The large number of young people as they become adult will 
require jobs and means to support themselves. 
 
Over the period 1985–1995, the economy grew with an annual average of 6.7% and this growth is largely due to the 
installation of hydropower schemes. However, the ninth 5-year plan says in Chapter 10 that provision of increased 
access to safe drinking water and improved sanitation are a top priority to further reduce the mortality and morbidity 
rate across the country. In Chapter 11, it stresses "as landlocked and mountainous country, the development of road 
infrastructure is of great importance for Bhutan for the delivery of social services as well as the development of private 
sector". The pressure of population growth on existing urban areas is beginning to have significant impacts and is the 
cause of considerable concern to the Government. Accompanying urban problems include a shortage of low-income 
housing; squatting on vacant government land; unplanned development of land on the periphery of the cities, without 
proper infrastructure and services; and problems associated with lack of roads, drainage, and adequate solid waste 
and sewerage disposal systems.  
B.  Poverty Analysis                                                                         Targeting Classification: General 
intervention 
What type of poverty analysis is needed?  
The most recent estimate of the population of Bhutan was 716,424 in 2002. Based on the 2000 Household Income 
and Expenditure Survey, preliminary lower and upper poverty lines have been established for Bhutan based on 
household expenditure levels. The incidence of poverty in Bhutan includes about 27% of households living at the 
upper poverty line (with Nu784.1 per capita per month), while 18% of households live below lower poverty line (with 
Nu612.1 per capita per month). Poverty concentrates in rural areas. This is due to limited amounts of cultivable land, 
the small size of land holdings, low productivity, and lack of market and services. The average household size in 
Bhutan is 5.5 persons; however, among rural populations, the average size of households varies between 7 and 8 
people. Rural households depend on diversity of economic activities to generate cash income and income varies by 
season. In urban areas, 70% percent of households rely on regular wages and salary, while 26% percent depend on 
self-employment.  The  overall  literacy  rate  in  Bhutan  is  46%.  From  existing  studies  conducted  by  the  Asian 
Development Bank in the past, and other sources of assistance, there are some existing data on the urban services 
coverage. As mentioned in main text (para 8), in Thimphu valley area, households connected to water supply are only 
30% and sanitation (sewerage) only 10%. Paved road connection is 30%. In Phuentsholing, water supply is relatively 
high at 80%, drainage at 45%; however, there is no public transport in the second largest town. In Dagana, less than 
30% of the population has any access to piped water, and no sanitation. According to the Danish International 
Development Agency's Urban Poverty Study (September 2002), it was reported that there are 544  "hutment" 
households in Thimphu, and only 50 or so in Phuentsholing. Most of them are encroaching on hilly slope land. In this 
study, in the two major cities, lowest income groups, which mainly consists of those "hutment" community is 
categorized as "lowest group" at Nu1,500–Nu2,000  per month consisting 2%–4% of whole households. The second 
lowest group is Nu2,500–Nu3,500 per month, at 10%–20% of households. The unemployment rate in the country is 
still 2%–3%, but in urban areas (i.e. in Thimphu and Phuentsholing), the rate is at 4.1%, and especially in the youth 
(15-19 years old), the figure is high at 10.9% in urban areas. There is considerable poverty analysis available for those 
"hutment" or squatter communities in Thimphu, but nothing has been done for Dagana or Mongar, districts unassisted 
by the aid community. Surveys including willingness-to-pay are needed.

C.  Participation Process 
Is there a stakeholder analysis?    Yes     No  
The technical assistance (TA) will consult with expected beneficiaries, especially low-income households in areas 
poorly served by infrastructure, other sources of aid, two city corporations, government agencies, and community and 
business leaders, through local hearings and other means. 
 
Is there a participation strategy?     Yes                   No 
The TA will actively engage selected urban communities in focus group discussions and consultative process with 
relevant municipalities to determine the financing schemes and post-project maintenance system. Especially in 
dzongkhag areas out of Thimphu and Phuentsholing, consultation will have to be very active to introduce charges for 
urban services for the first time.  
 
D.  Gender Development 
  
Strategy to maximize impacts on women: 
Over 45% of all employed Bhutanese are women. The majority of economically active women are engaged in 
agriculture. Around 28% are working as wageworkers. Also in the project area over 45% women are employed, of 
which 13% are engaged in nonagricultural business. Women are concentrated in low-skilled and low-paying jobs, 
informal sector micro-enterprises, and domestic service. In households, as with neighboring countries, women and 
children spend a considerable amount of time in the day fetching water for cooking and cleaning from wells and 
springs. For the introduction of sustainable maintenance of water provision, as off-set to improved quality and 
convenience, tariff introduction will be consulted and explained to the female household members thoroughly.

B.   Project Preparation 
 
3.  A  team  of  consultants  will  prepare  a  5-year  investment  project  to  improve  urban 
infrastructure and services in the targeted areas, following data collection, field surveys, and 
analysis, by undertaking the tasks described in Section C.

Appendix 4  11 
C.   Data and Information Collection and General Analysis  
 
4.  The  team  will  collect,  review,  update,  and  analyze  all  relevant  available  data  and 
information on and related to the project areas including (i) socioeconomic conditions, (ii) spatial 
and  physical  information,  (iii)  demographic  information,  (iv)  land  information,  and  (v) 
infrastructure inventory and urban services levels. It will conduct an initial social assessment to 
assess the extent of the social issues involved and to design subsequent survey and analyses 
appropriately. 
 
5.  The  consultants  will  collect,  review,  and  analyze  information  on  institutional 
arrangements,  policies,  and  regulations  including  those  on  land  and  property  taxes;  land 
acquisition;  resettlement;  rent  control;  government  housing  situation  (number,  size, 
maintenance, condition, budget, and rents); and government administration systems at national, 
district, local, and budgets and categories of expenditures, as well as sources of revenues at 
respective levels. They will also identify relevant investment and development programs from 
public and private sources, including external financing. The team will assess the total financial 
resources available for the urban development sector, including provincial and local government 
and external aid pipelines, and assess the country’s absorptive capacity of these resources. The 
consultants will ascertain the manner in which resources for capital works and the maintenance 
requirements in the project areas will be raised locally through taxes and charges and/or 
transferred from the national budget. Specifically, operation and maintenance arrangements and 
effective means of funding them adequately will be reviewed.  
 
6.  The team will carry out socioeconomic surveys in the project areas using the  Asian 
Development Bank's Handbook on Poverty and Social Analysis: A Working Document (2002). 
The  surveys  will  include  household  member  composition;  assessment  of  income  and 
expenditure distribution; expenditure patterns and cost of living; housing condition and living 
environment; incidence of diseases; allocation of personal time for various activities; frequency 
of use of commercial and amenity facilities and perception of urban infrastructure and services. 
The survey should be appropriately designed to establish the baseline information for estimating 
project  benefits  and  providing  project  justification,  and  to  analyze  the  affordability  and 
willingness-to-pay of the project especially for low-income groups. Also, the surveys should be 
used to judge the project's socioeconomic settings and to ensure that the project design reflects 
local needs, preferences, and concerns. The survey should include gender analyses using  
ADB's Gender Checklist on Resettlement (2003). The survey should cover all the project areas 
on a sample survey basis. Thematic base maps, plotting collected information such as land use, 
population distribution, infrastructure inventory, transport routes and facilities, trip patterns, and 
locations of important facilities and activities will be prepared.  
 
7.  Consultants will assess urbanization pressure on the project areas based on economic 
development and demographic trends. They will identify constraints in the capacity of urban 
infrastructure and housing, and estimate demand. The environmental implications of urban 
growth and development in the project areas will be examined, leading to suggestions for 
concrete policy introduction and legislative actions to prevent further urban sprawl and land 
speculation in urban areas.  
 
D.   Preparation of Urban Infrastructure 
 
8.  The team will develop a 5-year urban infrastructure improvement project taking into 
account possible trade-offs between long-term and medium-term solutions, ensuring that any 
component  of  the  prepared  project  is  sufficiently  justified.  It  will  prepare  preliminary  cost

12  Appendix 4 
estimates for each component. The costs should be broken down into direct and indirect foreign 
exchange costs and local currency costs. The costs should also be presented by generic 
category, i.e., by land, civil works, materials and equipment, consulting services, incremental 
administration, and operation and maintenance for each year. The tax and duty elements should 
be separately calculated for each budget item.  
 
9.   Financial analyses with sensitivity tests for revenue generating components will be 
conducted.  For  the  institution  that  undertakes  project  implementation,  the  consultants  will 
develop financial projections, assess the financial impact of the project on their finances in 
terms of capital and operation and maintenance in relation to cost recovery possibilities, and 
provide justification for their financial involvement. They will develop practicable cost recovery 
mechanisms for roads and stormwater drainage maintenance. 
 
10.  The team will conduct economic evaluation with sensitivity analyses of the project 
components. Unquantifiable benefits should be explicitly identified and assessed in qualitative 
terms. Financial and economic analyses will be performed in accordance with ADB's Guidelines 
for the Financial Management and Governance of Investment Projects Financed by the Asian 
Development Bank and Guidelines for the Economic Analysis of Projects and Handbook for the 
Economic  Analysis  of  Water  Supply  Projects.  The  economic  analysis  should  include  a 
qualitative analysis of risk, in line with ADB's  Handbook for Integrating Risk Analysis in the 
Economic Analysis of Projects. The consultants should estimate the detailed economic project 
cost  and  identify  all  quantifiable  and  unquantifiable  economic  benefits  from  the  project 
considering with and without-project scenarios, as well as incremental and non-incremental 
benefits. The team should also produce a financing plan using COSTAB software.  
 
11.   The consultants will identify the beneficiaries of the project and ensure that their needs 
and perceptions are consistent with the project’s objectives. They will conduct a social analysis 
identifying the social impact of the project especially on the urban poor and socially vulnerable 
groups of the population (women, children, the elderly, and the handicapped). If any component 
of the prepared  project involves resettlement, they will also prepare involuntary resettlement 
plan(s) in accordance with ADB's Involuntary Resettlement Policy (1995). 
 
12.  The team will develop social education and social participation programs as an important 
component of  the project so that proper operation and maintenance of the improved urban 
infrastructure is ensured with community participation and adequate practices of local residents. 
Particular attention should be paid to the improvement of the solid waste disposal practices, and 
to  maintenance  techniques  of  drainage  and  streams.  ADB's  Gender  Checklist  on  Urban 
Development and Housing will help to identify potential key gender issues for the ensuing loan 
to address. 
 
13.  A  project  implementation  schedule  and  arrangements  for  execution  of  all  project 
components will be developed. The consultants will establish functional relationships between 
participating  institutions,  assess  additional  staffing  needs  for  undertaking  project 
implementation, and indicate a phased staffing schedule. For the ensuing project, they will 
develop  an  appropriately  staffed  and  fully  costed  proposal  for  project  management  and 
engineering design consulting services with a draft outline terms of reference.  
 
14.  A logical framework for the project will be developed in consultation with government 
agencies and local communities, with the objective of enhancing the level of participation of 
beneficiaries and stakeholders. The logical framework will be based on ADB practice and will 
include goals, objectives, outputs, inputs and activities, key risks and assumptions, and project

Appendix 4  13 
costs. In addition, a project performance monitoring system will be established for the ensuing 
loan, based on baseline information collected during the TA, that encompasses the logical 
framework  (cf.  http://www.adb.org/ppms/).  The  monitoring  system  should  include  progress 
reports and discussions with all stakeholders, ensuring that the beneficiaries also undertake 
evaluation.  
 
15.  Through public consultation at early stage of the TA, the team will develop and integrate 
into the project environmental monitoring and control mechanisms to protect and enhance the 
quality of the urban environment in the project areas. It will conduct a comprehensive appraisal 
of  the  environmental  impacts  of  the  project  components,  design  appropriate  mitigation 
measures (including costs), prepare an initial environmental examination in accordance with 
ADB's Environmental Assessment Guidelines (2003), environmental assessment requirements, 
and environmental review procedures. The team will develop an environmental management 
plan (including monitoring indicators and a monitoring plan, and organizational arrangements for 
implementing the mitigation program). It will also examine the need for an environmental impact 
assessment and prepare draft outline terms of reference for such an assessment, if required.  
 
16.   The consultants will formulate a program of institutional strengthening and policy reforms 
as a first phase element of the project. This program will strengthen Thimphu and Phuentsholing 
city  corporations  and  selected  dzongkhag  (provincial)  administration  in  undertaking  urban 
management responsibilities relating to the management of urban infrastructure and services, 
including (i) operation and maintenance of urban infrastructure and provision of urban services, 
(ii) management of capital investment projects, and (iii) municipal financial management such as 
collection of taxes and charges as well as and budgeting. This program will include on-the-job 
training of staff indicated (i) to (iii) above and necessary equipment. They will identify also any 
impediments  that  would  constrain  the  project  implementation  including  policy,  legal,  and 
institutional set up.  
 
E.   Specific Tasks Associated with the Team Leader1 
 
17.   Civil Engineer (Road/Bridge/Traffic Management)/Team Leader. The team leader will 
organize and manage the consulting team and coordinate the overall TA. The leader will 
coordinate the preparation of all documentation required by ADB guidelines and the ADB project 
officer to develop the report and recommendation of the President document for the ensuing 
loan,  including  (i)  a  detailed  project  framework;  (ii)  project  performance  monitoring  and 
evaluation arrangements, including baseline data; and  (iii) an assessment of the detailed 
procurement and implementation arrangements. The team leader will be accountable for the 
quality and timeliness of all deliverables, and will ensure that all components are clearly and 
concisely documented to the full satisfaction of the ADB project team. The team leader will also 
be responsible for ensuring that the proposed investment that will be prepared through the TA is 
complete, cohesive, economically and financially viable, and in full compliance with all pertinent 
ADB and government policies and guidelines. The team leader will also work on the selection of 
regional centers to be targeted for this project in consultation with ADB and the Government. 
The team leader will also be in Bhutan to help the ADB project officer when reviewing the 
progress of the TA.
